body: I'm sympathetic to the wish that it is set by default. I didn't have a strong opinion either way, and I can be easily convinced that it *should* check by default. Or, perhaps just offer an option on the `ClientBuilder`.

+1 from me also. For example the most popular Python http client library [does support system proxy by default](http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#proxies). What is the downside of supporting proxy automatically?

Yea, I'm fine with doing this. Here's what I'd recommend we do:

- Use something like the [env_proxy](https://crates.io/crates/env_proxy) crate. This can be combined with `reqwest::Proxy::custom`.
- Check if the appropriate environment variables are set at all. This is needed so that we don't create a "custom" proxy if none of the variables are set.
- Add a `ClientBuilder` option to disable checking the environment.

How does that sound?

Yeah that sounds great. From my experience most developers using the higher level library like this one expect things to just work. So that should be default. In rare cases you want to have way to ignore the system proxy, so the override needs to be there.

From user standpoint working in a network where we are restricted to proxy connections, I often find that the tools don't work, because most developers don't develop in such environment. So supporting it by default will make this crate and any projects using it way more useful for users like me.

I'm not sure if you need to check the proxy env variables. Maybe check with [`for_url`](https://inejge.github.io/env_proxy/env_proxy/fn.for_url.html) the specific URL if that's an option? Proxy might be required for some, but not for some other depending on `no_proxy` settings. (This is often the case in proxied networks, where internal resources are accessed directly while external might be only accessed via proxy)

[`for_url`](https://inejge.github.io/env_proxy/env_proxy/fn.for_url.html) is the way to go imo. `no_proxy` is a must for users behind corporate networks. ~~On that note, is there a way right now to disable proxy for `reqwest::Client`? Something along the lines of `ClientBuilder::new().proxy(None)`?~~ `ClientBuilder::new().proxy(Proxy::custom(|_| None))` works.

issue.title: Add proxy support

repository.name: hors
repository.description: instant coding answers via the command line (howdoi in rust)

issue.body:
Just think that `hors` should support proxy, so user don't need to care about system http proxy anymore.
And it's better to solve in the `reqwest` module (here is the relative issue: https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues/403).  So I can just upgrade `reqwest` version without changing anycode.

issue.title: Try to make reqwest use system proxies.

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
Try to resolve issue #403 
The core function for this feature is `get_proxies()`, which is a copy from `python` [getproxies implementation](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/urllib/request.py).

### Some consideration about the design:
After looking the `getproxies` implementation in python, I don't whink we need to use something like [env_proxy] crate, because it doesn't support `windows system`.  So I implement it once again..  And this version of `getproxies` should work on `windows` and `linux`.

### Something about testing
In `windows` system, because the proxy setting is configured from `registry`.  I just do manually testing for this scenario.  (I have implemented it [in another place first](https://github.com/WindSoilder/hors/blob/master/src/proxies.rs))
I'm afraid the testing code may break `windows registry setting`.  It can be a very big problem.  So I just leave it away :(

body: Any plans to flip the switch to enable this by default?

issue.title: Enable "system" proxies by default

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
If no proxies are configured for a client, the environment (system) will
be inspected automatically to set up proxies.

Configuring a `Proxy` on a client or calling `no_proxy` will disable the
use of the automatic system proxy.

Closes #403
